metadata.title: The securetcpip command must be used.
metadata.description: The securetcpip command must be used.

metadata.title: The SYSTEM attribute must not be set to NONE for any account.
metadata.description: The SYSTEM attribute must not be set to NONE for any account.

criterion.comment: all instances of SYSTEM are OK

metadata.title: The /etc/netsvc.conf file must be root owned.
metadata.description: The /etc/netsvc.conf file is used to specify the ordering of name resolution for the sendmail command, alias resolution for the sendmail command, and host name resolution routines. Malicious changes could prevent the system from functioning correctly or compromise system security.

metadata.title: The /etc/netsvc.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/netsvc.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/netsvc.conf is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The system must not allow directed broadcasts to gateway.
metadata.description: Disabling directed_broadcast prevents packets directed to a gateway to be broadcasted on a remote network.

metadata.title: The system must provide protection from Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) attacks on TCP connections.
metadata.description: The system must provide protection from Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) attacks on TCP connections.

metadata.title: System must provide protection for the TCP stack against connection resets, SYN and data injection attacks.
metadata.description: System must provide protection for the TCP stack against connection resets, SYN and data injection attacks.

metadata.title: The system must provide protection against IP fragmentation attacks.
metadata.description: The system must provide protection against IP fragmentation attacks.

metadata.title: The system must not have the bootp service active.
metadata.description: The system must not have the bootp service active.

criterion.comment: no bootps arg (in case using tcpd)

metadata.title: The /etc/ftpaccess.ctl file must exist.
metadata.description: The /etc/ftpaccess.ctl file must exist.

metadata.title: The /etc/ftpaccess.ctl file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/ftpaccess.ctl file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/ftpaccess.ctl file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/ftpaccess.ctl is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: The operating system must be a supported release.
metadata.description: The operating system must be a supported release.

criterion.comment: Installed operating system is part of the Unix family
Installed operation system is IBM AIX 6.1

metadata.title: The system clock must be synchronized continuously, or at least daily.
metadata.description: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. Internal system clocks tend to drift and require periodic resynchronization to ensure their accuracy. Software, such as ntpd, can be used to continuously synchronize the system clock with authoritative sources. Alternatively, the system may be synchronized periodically, with a maximum of one day between synchronizations.

criterion.comment: ntpdate is invoked by cron at least daily

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be owned by root.
metadata.description: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised. If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.

metadata.title: All GIDs referenced in the /etc/passwd file must be defined in the /etc/group file.
metadata.description: If a user is assigned the GID of a group that does not exist on the system, and a group with that GID is subsequently created, the user may have unintended rights to that group.

criterion.comment: All GIDs in /etc/passwd must be defined in /etc/group

metadata.title: The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, console login prompts.
metadata.description: The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, console login prompts.

criterion.comment: all instances of herald are the DoD login banner

metadata.title: The FTPS/FTP service on the system must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner.
metadata.description: The FTPS/FTP service on the system must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner.

criterion.comment: DoD Login Banner is configured for ftpd

metadata.title: The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts.
metadata.description: The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts.

criteria.comment: all instances of loginretries are OK

criterion.comment: no instance of loginretries is greater than 3

metadata.title: The delay between login prompts following a failed login attempt must be at least 4 seconds.
metadata.description: The delay between login prompts following a failed login attempt must be at least 4 seconds.

criterion.comment: no instance of logindelay is less than 4

metadata.title: Users must not be able to change passwords more than once every 24 hours.
metadata.description: Users must not be able to change passwords more than once every 24 hours.

criterion.comment: all instances of minage are OK

metadata.title: The system must not have accounts configured with blank or null passwords.
metadata.description: If an account is configured for password authentication but does not have an assigned password, it may be possible to log into the account without authentication. If the root user is configured without a password, the entire system may be compromised. For user accounts not using password authentication, the account must be configured with a password lock value instead of a blank or null value.

criterion.comment: All users have a stanza in /etc/security/passwd

metadata.title: The system must require passwords to contain a minimum of 15 characters.
metadata.description: The system must require passwords to contain a minimum of 15 characters.

criterion.comment: all instances of minlen are OK

metadata.title: The system must enforce the correctness of the entire password during authentication.
metadata.description: The system must enforce the correctness of the entire password during authentication.

criterion.comment: All passwd entries in /etc/security/passwd are sha256 or sha512

metadata.title: The password hashes stored on the system must have been generated using a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm.
metadata.description: The password hashes stored on the system must have been generated using a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm.

criterion.comment: All passwd entries in /etc/security/passwd are sha256 or sha512

metadata.title: The system must require that passwords contain at least one special character.
metadata.description: The system must require that passwords contain at least one special character.

criterion.comment: all instances of minother are OK

metadata.title: The system must require passwords to contain no more than three consecutive repeating characters.
metadata.description: The system must require passwords to contain no more than three consecutive repeating characters.

criterion.comment: all instances of maxrepeats are OK

metadata.title: User passwords must be changed at least every 60 days.
metadata.description: User passwords must be changed at least every 60 days.

criteria.comment: all instances of maxage are OK

criterion.comment: no instance of maxage is greater than 8

metadata.title: The system must require at least eight characters be changed between the old and new passwords during a password change.
metadata.description: The system must require at least eight characters be changed between the old and new passwords during a password change.

criterion.comment: all instances of mindiff are OK

metadata.title: The system must prevent the use of dictionary words for passwords.
metadata.description: The system must prevent the use of dictionary words for passwords.

criterion.comment: all instances of dictionlist are OK

metadata.title: The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations.
metadata.description: The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations.

criterion.comment: all instances of histsize are OK

metadata.title: The system must restrict the ability to switch to the root user to members of a defined group.
metadata.description: The system must restrict the ability to switch to the root user to members of a defined group.

metadata.title: The root account must be the only account having a UID of 0.
metadata.description: If an account has a UID of 0, it has root authority. Multiple accounts with a UID of 0 afford more opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account.

criterion.comment: No non-root account may have UID 0

metadata.title: The root user's home directory must not be the root directory (/).
metadata.description: Changing the root home directory to something other than / and assigning it a 0700 protection makes it more difficult for intruders to manipulate the system by reading the files that root places in its default directory. It also gives root the same discretionary access control for root's home directory as for the other plain user home directories.

metadata.title: The root account's home directory (other than /) must have mode 0700.
metadata.description: Permissions greater than 0700 could allow unauthorized users access to the root home directory.

criteria.comment: IF ~root is not / THEN ~root's perms should be 0700

metadata.title: The root account's executable search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The root account's executable search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.

metadata.title: The root account's library search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The root account's library search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.

metadata.title: The root account's list of preloaded libraries must be empty.
metadata.description: The root account's list of preloaded libraries must be empty.

metadata.title: The root account must not have world-writable directories in its executable search path.
metadata.description: The root account must not have world-writable directories in its executable search path.

criterion.comment: root executable search path no world-writable directories

metadata.title: The system must prevent the root account from directly logging in except from the system console.
metadata.description: The system must prevent the root account from directly logging in except from the system console.

criterion.comment: root has rlogin specified and set to false

metadata.title: Remote consoles must be disabled or protected from unauthorized access.
metadata.description: Remote consoles must be disabled or protected from unauthorized access.

metadata.title: All system command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Restricting permissions will protect system command files from unauthorized modification.

criteria.comment: All system command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

criterion.comment: All files in system command directories

metadata.title: System log files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: System log files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.

metadata.title: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin.
metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.

criteria.comment: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin.

criterion.comment: /var/yp files owned by root, bin, or sys
/var/nis files owned by root, bin, or sys
/usr/lib/nis files owned by root, bin, or sys
/usr/lib/netsvc/yp files owned by root, bin, or sys

metadata.title: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be group-owned by sys, bin, other, or system.
metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be group-owned by sys, bin, other, or system.

criterion.comment: nis files growned by system, bin, or sys

metadata.title: The NIS/NIS+/yp files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: The NIS/NIS+/yp files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

metadata.title: The /etc/resolv.conf file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/resolv.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/resolv.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/resolv.conf is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The /etc/hosts file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/hosts file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/hosts file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/hosts is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The /etc/passwd file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: GEN001379
metadata.description: The /etc/passwd file must be group-owned by system, bin, sys, security.

metadata.title: The /etc/passwd file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/passwd is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The /etc/group file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/group File Group Ownership
metadata.description: The /etc/group file must be group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security

criterion.comment: /etc/group file group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security

metadata.title: The /etc/group file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/group is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The /etc/shadow (or equivalent) file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/security/passwd file must be group-owned by security, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: The /etc/security/passwd file must be group-owned by security, bin, sys, or system.

criterion.comment: /etc/security/passwd growned by security, system, bin, or sys

metadata.title: The /etc/security/passwd file must have mode 0400.
metadata.description: The /etc/security/passwd file must have mode 0400.

metadata.title: The /etc/group file must not contain any group password hashes.
metadata.description: Group passwords are typically shared and should not be used. Additionally, if password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.

metadata.title: Ensure that User Home Directories are not Group-Writable or World-Readable
metadata.description: File permissions should be set correctly for the home directories for all user accounts.

metadata.title: Global Initialization Files Permissions
metadata.description: All global initialization files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.

metadata.title: Global Initialization Files Ownership
metadata.description: All global initialization files must be owned by root.

criterion.comment: check /etc/.login file is owned by root
check /etc/profile file is owned by root
check /etc/bashrc file is owned by root
check /etc/environment file is owned by root
check /etc/security/environ file is owned by root
check /etc/security/.profile file is owned by root
check /etc/csh.login file is owned by root
check /etc/csh.cshrc file is owned by root

metadata.title: Global Initialization Files Group Ownership
metadata.description: All global initialization files must be group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security

criterion.comment: check /etc/.login file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security
check /etc/profile file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security
check /etc/bashrc file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security
check /etc/environment file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security
check /etc/security/environ file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security
check /etc/security/.profile file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security
check /etc/csh.login file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security
check /etc/csh.cshrc file is group-owned by system, bin, sys, or security

metadata.title: Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands.
metadata.description: If the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" command is not placed into the system profile, messaging can be used to cause a denial of service attack.

criteria.comment: Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands.

criterion.comment: Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (csh.cshrc)
Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (security/.profile)
Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (csh.login)
Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (bashrc)
Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (profile)
Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (environment)
Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (security/environ)
Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands. (.login)

metadata.title: All skeleton files (typically those in /etc/skel) must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/security/.profile is 644 or less permissive
Test mode of /etc/security/mkuser.sys is 755 or less permissive

metadata.title: Default/Skeleton Dot Files Ownership
metadata.description: All skeleton files and directories must be owned by root or bin.

metadata.title: GEN001830
metadata.description: All skeleton files must be group-owned by security.

metadata.title: There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system.
metadata.description: There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system.

metadata.title: Cron Utility Accessibility
metadata.description: Access to the cron utility must be controlled using the cron.allow and/or cron.deny file(s)

metadata.title: The cron.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/adm/cron/cron.allow is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: Crontab files must have mode 0600 or less permissive, and files in cron script directories must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/spool/cron/crontabs/* is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: Cron and crontab directories must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/spool/cron/crontabs is 755 or less permissive

metadata.title: Cron and crontab directories must be owned by root or bin.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: Cron and Crontab Directories Group Ownership
metadata.description: Cron and crontab directories must be group-owned by system, bin, sys, or cron

criterion.comment: /var/spool/cron/crontabs directory group-owned by system, bin, sys, or cron

metadata.title: The cron.deny file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/adm/cron/cron.deny is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: The cron.allow file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The cron.allow file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The at.deny file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/adm/cron/at.deny is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: The cron.deny file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The cron.deny File Group Ownership
metadata.description: The cron.deny file must be group-owned by system, bin, sys, or cron

criterion.comment: cron.deny file group-owned by system, bin, sys, or cron

metadata.title: At Utility Accessibility
metadata.description: Access to the "at" utility must be controlled via the at.allow and/or at.deny file(s)

metadata.title: The at.deny file
metadata.description: The at.deny file must not be empty if it exists

metadata.title: Default System Accounts and At
metadata.description: Default system accounts (with the exception of root) must not be listed in the at.allow file or must be included in the at.deny file if the at.allow file does not exist

criterion.comment: default system accounts (other than root) are not listed in /var/adm/cron/at.allow
default system accounts (other than root) are listed in /var/adm/cron/at.deny

metadata.title: The at.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive
metadata.description: The at.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive

metadata.title: The at directory permissions
metadata.description: The "at" directory must have mode 0755 or less permissive

metadata.title: The "at" directory must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The at.allow file must be owned by root, bin, or sys
metadata.description: The at.allow file must be owned by root, bin, or sys

metadata.title: The at.allow file must be group-owned by system, bin, sys, or cron
metadata.description: The at.allow file must be group-owned by system, bin, sys, or cron

metadata.title: The at.deny file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The at.deny file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: Process core dumps must be disabled unless needed.
metadata.description: Process core dumps must be disabled unless needed.

criterion.comment: all instances of core are OK

metadata.title: The system must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets.
metadata.description: The system must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets.

metadata.title: TCP backlog queue sizes must be set appropriately.
metadata.description: TCP backlog queue sizes must be set appropriately.

metadata.title: The system must prevent local applications from generating source-routed packets.
metadata.description: The system must prevent local applications from generating source-routed packets.

metadata.title: The system must not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.
metadata.description: The system must not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.

metadata.title: The system must ignore IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.
metadata.description: The system must ignore IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.

metadata.title: The system must not send IPv4 ICMP redirects.
metadata.description: The system must not send IPv4 ICMP redirects.

metadata.title: The system must be configured to use TCP syncookies when experiencing a TCP SYN flood.
metadata.description: The system must be configured to use TCP syncookies when experiencing a TCP SYN flood.

metadata.title: The inetd.conf file, xinetd.conf file, and the xinetd.d directory must be owned by root or bin.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The inetd.conf file, xinetd.conf file, and the xinetd.d directory must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The inetd.conf and xinetd.conf files must have mode 0440 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/inetd.conf is 440 or less permissive

metadata.title: The services file must be owned by root or bin.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The services file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The services file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/services is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The portmap or rpcbind service must not be installed unless needed.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /usr/sbin/portmap is 0 or less permissive

metadata.title: The rsh daemon must not be running.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement that the rsh daemon is not running.

metadata.title: The rlogind service must not be running.
metadata.description: The rlogind service must not be running.

metadata.title: The rexec daemon must not be running.
metadata.description: The rexecd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service. SSH should be used in place of this service.

metadata.title: The telnet daemon must not be running.
metadata.description: The telnet daemon provides a typically unencrypted remote access service which does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session. If a privileged user were to log on using this service, the privileged user password could be compromised.

metadata.title: The system must not have the finger service active.
metadata.description: The finger service provides information about the system's users to network clients. This information could expose information that could be used in subsequent attacks.

metadata.title: Network analysis tools must not be installed.
metadata.description: Network analysis tools must not be installed.

metadata.title: GEN003930
metadata.description: The hosts.lpd file must be group-owned by system, bin, or sys

metadata.title: GEN003960
metadata.description: The traceroute command owner must be root

metadata.title: The traceroute command must be group-owned by sys, bin, root, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The traceroute file must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /usr/bin/traceroute is 700 or less permissive

metadata.title: The alias file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: GEN004370
metadata.description: The aliases file must be group-owned by system, bin, sys

metadata.title: aliases permissions
metadata.description: The alias file must have mode 0644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The system must not use .forward files.
metadata.description: The system must not use .forward files.

metadata.title: The ftpusers file
metadata.description: The ftpusers file must exist

metadata.title: The ftpusers file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The ftpusers file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The ftpusers file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/ftpusers is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: Anonymous FTP accounts must not have a functional shell.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test for an anonymous ftp user in the /etc/passwd

metadata.title: The /etc/syslog.conf file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/syslog.conf is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: The /etc/syslog.conf file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /etc/syslog.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to not use CBC-based ciphers.
metadata.description: The cipher-block chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen plain text attacks and must not be used.

criterion.comment: ssh_config does not use CBC ciphers

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to only use message authentication codes (MACs) that employ FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms.
metadata.description: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups.
metadata.description: Restricting SSH logins to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to restrict logins to specific users and/or groups

metadata.title: The SSH public host key files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If a public host key file is modified by an unauthorized user, the SSH service may be compromised.

metadata.title: The SSH private host key files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/ssh/*key is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the systems GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to disallow GSSAPI authentication

metadata.title: The SSH client must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the systems GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criterion.comment: SSH client is configured to disallow GSSAPI authentication

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not permit Kerberos authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: Kerberos authentication for SSH is often implemented using GSSAPI. If Kerberos is enabled through SSH, the SSH daemon provides a means of access to the system's Kerberos implementation. Vulnerabilities in the system's Kerberos implementation may then be subject to exploitation. To reduce the attack surface of the system, the Kerberos authentication mechanism within SSH must be disabled for systems not using this capability.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to disallow Kerberos authentication

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must perform strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
metadata.description: If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log into the system as another user.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must use privilege separation.
metadata.description: SSH daemon privilege separation causes the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed, which would decrease the impact of software vulnerabilities in the unprivileged section.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.
metadata.description: If SSH permits rhosts RSA authentication, a user may be able to log in based on the keys of the host originating the request and not any user-specific authentication.

criteria.comment: The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.
metadata.description: If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection, potentially with root priveleges.

metadata.title: The NFS export configuration file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The NFS export configuration file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/exports is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The smb.conf file must be owned by root
metadata.description: The smb.conf file must be owned by root

metadata.title: The smb.conf file must be group-owned by system, bin, or sys
metadata.description: The smb.conf file must be group-owned by system, bin, or sys

metadata.title: The smb.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive
metadata.description: The smb.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The smbpasswd file must be owned by root
metadata.description: The smbpasswd file must be owned by root

metadata.title: The smbpasswd file must be group-owned by system or sys
metadata.description: The smbpasswd file must be group-owned by system or sys

metadata.title: The smbpasswd file must have mode 0600 or less permissive
metadata.description: The smbpasswd file must have mode 0600 or less permissive

metadata.title: The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.
metadata.description: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.

criterion.comment: There is a default deny all entry in /etc/hosts.deny

metadata.title: The DHCP client must be disabled if not needed.
metadata.description: DHCP allows for the unauthenticated configuration of network parameters on the system by exchanging information with a DHCP server.

criterion.comment: There must be no DHCP client running.

metadata.title: The DHCP client must not send dynamic DNS updates.
metadata.description: Dynamic DNS updates transmit unencrypted information about a system including its name and address and should not be used unless needed.

criterion.comment: The DHCP client does not send dynamic DNS updates.

metadata.title: The system must ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
metadata.description: The system must ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.

metadata.title: The system must not send IPv6 ICMP redirects.
metadata.description: The system must not send IPv6 ICMP redirects.

metadata.title: The system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.
metadata.description: The system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.

metadata.title: The system must not accept source-routed IPv6 packets.
metadata.description: The system must not accept source-routed IPv6 packets.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information the /etc/ldap.conf (or equivalent) file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/security/ldap/ldap.cfg is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the /etc/ldap.conf (or equivalent) file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The group owner of the /etc/security/ldap/ldap.cfg file
metadata.description: The group owner of the /etc/security/ldap/ldap.cfg file

metadata.title: The system must not have the chargen service active.
metadata.description: When contacted, chargen responds with some random characters. When contacted via UDP, it will respond with a single UDP packet. When contacted via TCP, it will continue spewing characters until the client closes the connection. An easy attack is 'ping-pong' in which an attacker spoofs a packet between two machines running chargen. This will cause them to spew characters at each other, slowing the machines down and saturating the network. The chargen service is unnecessary and provides an opportunity for DoS attack.

metadata.title: The system must not have the Calendar Manager Service Daemon (CMSD) service active.
metadata.description: The CMSD service for CDE is an unnecessary process that runs a root and increases attack vector of the system. Buffer overflow attacks against the CMSD process can potentially give access to the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have the tool-talk database server (ttdbserver) service active.
metadata.description: The ttdbserver service for CDE is an unnecessary service that runs as root and might be compromised.

metadata.title: The system must not have the comsat service active.
metadata.description: The comsat daemon notifies users on incoming email. This is an unnecessary service and is vulnerable to a flood attack. Running unnecessary services increases the attack vector of the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have the daytime service active.
metadata.description: The daytime service runs as root from the inetd daemon and can provide an opportunity for Denial of Service PING or PING-PONG attacks. The daytime service is unnecessary and it increases the attack vector of the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have the discard service active.
metadata.description: The discard service runs as root from the inetd server and can be used in Denial of Service attacks. The discard service is unnecessary and it increases the attack vector of the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have dtspc service active.
metadata.description: This service is started automatically by the inetd daemon with root permission in response to a CDE client requesting a process to be started on the daemon's host system. Running the dtscp service is unnecessary and it increases the attack vector of the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have the echo service active.
metadata.description: The echo service can be used in Denial of Service or SMURF attacks. It can also used at someone else to get through a firewall or start a data storm. The echo service is unnecessary and it increases the attack vector of the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) service active.
metadata.description: The IMAP service should not be running unless the system is acting as a mail server for client connections. Running unnecessary services increases the attack vector on the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have the PostOffice Protocol (POP3) service active.
metadata.description: The POP3 service is only needed if the server is acting as a mail server and clients are using applications that only support POP3. Users' ids and passwords are sent in plain text to the POP3 service. If mail client access is needed, consider using IMAP or SSL enabled POP3.

metadata.title: The system must not have the talk or ntalk services active.
metadata.description: The talk and ntalk commands allow users on the same or different systems on converse. The talk daemons are started from the inetd process and run as root. These unnecessary processes increase the attack vector of the system and may cause Denial of Service by scrambling the users display.

metadata.title: The system must not have the netstat service active on the inetd process.
metadata.description: The netstat service can potentially give out network information on active connections if it is running. The information given out can aid in an attack and weaken the systems defensive posture.

metadata.title: The system must not have the PCNFS service active.
metadata.description: The PCNFS service predates Microsofts SMB specifications. If a similar service is needed to share files from a Windows based OS to a UNIX based OS, consider SAMBA.

metadata.title: The system must not have the systat service active.
metadata.description: The systat daemon allows remote users to see the running process and who is running them. This may aid in information collection for an attack and weaken the security posture of the system.

metadata.title: The /etc/inetd time service must not be active on the system on the inetd daemon.
metadata.description: The time service is an internal inetd function is used by the rdate command. This service is sometimes used to synchronize clocks at boot time. The service is outdated. Use the ntpdate command instead.

metadata.title: The system must not have the rusersd service active.
metadata.description: The rusersd daemon gives out a list of current uses on the system. The rusersd daemon is unnecessary and it increases the attack vector of the system by providing information on the current users of the system.

metadata.title: The system must not have the sprayd service active.
metadata.description: The sprayd service is sometimes used for network and nfs troubleshooting. The spray service can be used for both buffer overflow and Denial of Service attacks by saturating the network. The sprayd daemon is an unnecessary service.

metadata.title: The system must not have the rstatd service active.
metadata.description: The rstatd can give out information on the running system such as the CPU usage, the system uptime, its network usage and other system information that could potentially aid in an attack. The rstatd service is unnecessary and it weakens the defensive posture of the system. If systems monitoring is needed, use a third party tool or snmp.
